msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth
to Mrs. Griffith, , April 20th 1826

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in a manuscript. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p: I have made many attempts but have not yet succeeded in collecting means of an- swering the various questions and interest ing subjects of discussion in your last kind letter - I have shown the very pretty and useful & ingenious model of your beehive to all whom it might concern in my neighbor hood - I cannot say that there any among our neighbors who deserve to be called apiarists as they have none of them a sufficient num- ber of beehives or sufficient experience - But they have sense enough to see the value of your bee hive and I am sure it will be imitated successfully. - I have sent, through Lord Oriel a description of it in your own & in Mr. Balstones words to the Horticultural Society at Kew and have waited with too great patience for their acknowledgment and for their reply to your observations on boring which I also copied for them - From another friend who has experience on the subject I also ex pect some information & from my brother William hope for some when he returns home - but he is at present absence & engaged so much professionally that he has scarcely time to write the shortest letters home

The situation of Sir Walter Scott's affairs has and my knowing how very busy he has been have prevented me from yet forwarding to him the copy of Mr. Bryant's poems which you sent me for him - but I will do so now that he is more at leisure and that I see Woodstock is out - as this days paper informs me - You will be glad to hear that his losses are not so great as report made them - He has lost about 30,000 Sterling - but Abbotsford and his library - and his tem- per - and his gaité de coeur are all safe - One question of yours I can answer - Why did Sir Walter Scott not mention Miss Austin in his lives of the British novellists Not Because he undervalued her talents - of that he is incapable - But simply because the work was continued only to the time of Cum- berland whose novels were published many years before Miss Austins - The work did not succeed & was discontinued - These lives which were intended to be prefixed to the works of each of the author were never published separately in these countries - Galignani had the sense to republish them in Paris in his newspaper & then finding how much they were admired, published them in two small volumes in the form in which they now appear - Beautiful specimens of biography & criticism they are! - In my opinion fully equal & in some parts superior in interest and literary value to Dr Johnson's prefaces. - They are not so dogmatic, and they contain are more philosophical criticism - They are peculiarly interesting as containing the opinions & letting us into some of the principles of com- position of one who has so eminently excelled both as a poet, and an inventor & an author of fictitious narratives - Johnson can hardly

be called a poet - except a satirical poet - (See London & the Vanity of human wishes - that is all - And as for invention, - the only example we have of any invention of his is in Rasselas - I have not time to - and in that the insane phi losopher who fancied he ruled the weather is the only quite new & original invention I can recollect of Johnson - As to Scott ~~ who alive or dead except Shakespear can stand a comparison with him in invention, - the true test of genius I am very much afraid that I shall never be able to satisfy you about the ( Last of the Mohicans - But it is early times with us yet - as we began it only last night and have read only 20 pages - Thank you for it however my dear Madam at all events - and give me credit for my sincerity. If in my next letter when we have read the whole I can tell you I like it you will have faith in my praises. April 21st. Last night we got into the cavern & that is a sublime scene - We began to be much interested - I merely wrote a few lines to you at present to assure you that I am not ungrateful for all your kind attentions. The specimens of the ground pine and of the festoon pine have delighted me and many of my more deserving botanical friends - I beg you will not make any more attempts to send me sweetmeats - I am quite ashamed! - I am assured that no captain of any vessel will take charge of them - except it be a captain of an English man of war or frigate -- I have half a mind to beg from you a draught or chess board or wash bord to be made of specimens of American woods - the beauty of the wood of which your model of a beehive was made put this idea into my head & the nicety of the workmanship shewed me that your American

workmen can vye with our best cabinetmakers - I am very sorry indeed to hear such bad accounts of the maddens - But I cannot yet believe that Madden has turned out dishonest -- Tho I said I wd write only a few lines I must write more - I am at this moment in great perplexity - A very dear & very amiable - entertaining & improvident friend of mine, long known & long loved by my father & by all our family has now just suddenly died & left a widow & 7 children of all ages from 22 to 10 years old absolutely unprovided for - after having lived till now in affluence & in the best society in this country - The gentleman was a clergyman - I am ashamed to confess to you that he had a living of eighteen hundred a year - but he lived up to it as we say in this country - Mrs. J every year attempted to lay by something but he continually broke in upon her fund - And suddenly in the prime of life he was snatched away! Mrs. Johnson has been an exemplary wife & mother - Her daughters, two of them are beauti ful - all of them accomplished & well informed, with peculiar natural & acquired talents vocal & instrumental for music - They in the midst of this sudden distress turn their minds at once to consider how they can assist their mother in supporting themselves inde pendantly - It has been suggested that they might take a house at Bath & receive two or 3 unmarried young ladies as lodgers who might have the advantage of the protection & society of a lady of good family the habits of good company) good principles With Mrs. Johnson & also the advantage of her musical practice & instruction from herself and her daughters should be considered Would such a plan succeed in Philadelphia - or new york? Could 2 or 3 boarders be secured who could pay 2 hundred a year? Would the young ladies be likely to establish themselves well?
